Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Radiation selectivity of photo-induced structural transformations in covalently bonded glassy thin films
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Chalcogenide glass thin films, due to their multifunctionality and unique properties, are remarkably promising materials for emerging applications in infrared photonics, non-linear optics, all-optical computing, micro(nano)-lithography, and phase-change memory devices. These materials are exceptional because of their multilevel sensitivity to exposure by light or particles (electrons, neutrons, ions); this sensitivity depends on the intensity and energy of the radiation source. Light treatment can also be used to accelerate structural relaxation in amorphous films, stabilizing their properties for further applications. However, to control the photo-(or light-)induced effects and predict behavior of the exposed material, the mechanisms of photostructural transformation on the surface and inside of the films at different light energies and intensities needs to be better understood. The goal of this project is to develop, using advanced experimental methods, a new level of understanding of the photostructural transformations and establish an efficient way to stabilize the structural relaxation of chalcogenide glass thin films prepared by different methods. Undergraduate research is an essential part of the project, providing students access to the advanced experimental facilities and inspiring them to consider a career in science or engineering.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: As-S(Se) (pyramidal) and Ge-S(Se) (tetrahedral) binary chalcogenide glass thin films, within a wide compositional domain, thermally deposited in vacuum as well as spin-coated from solution are being studied. The thermally-deposited films are known for their high photosensitivity and a large concentration of homopolar bonds, even for stoichiometric compositions. While, the spin-coated films are relatively photo-stable with structure close to the bulk analogue. The project's planned outcome is an atomistic picture of the structural response to photoexposure and its dependence on photon energy and fluence for pyramidal and tetrahedral chalcogenide glass thin films obtained with the two different methods. The mechanisms of photostructural transformations are studied with Raman microscopy, high-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, optical spectroscopy, X-ray absorption and neutron scattering methods. The project's results have the potential to stimulate major progress in application of chalcogenide glass thin films in emerging fields such as photonics, memory devices, and micro/nanolithography. As well, one of the main objectives of the project is the development of a nationally recognizable undergraduate research training program in experimental and computational glass science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This RUI (Research in Undergraduate Institutions) project had several distinct scientific outcomes as well as a significant educational impact including outreach to high school and elementary school students leading to the establishment of a strong, internationally recognized undergraduate research program in glass science at a regional university in middle Tennessee, which serves a largely rural population with a high number of first-generation college students.

Scientifically, this project contributed to deeper understanding of how light of different energies and intensities influences the optical properties of amorphous photosensitive thin films made from non-oxide chalcogenide glasses and how these changes are related to the modification of the electronic and atomic structure of both thermally deposited (in vacuum) and spin-coated (from solution) thin films. Results of this project will allow scientists and engineers to optimize these films to suppress the long, irreversible component of light-induced optical effects, such as those associated with photo-aging.  The results also help to find materials with intense, fast transient optical components as well as thin films which are stable to the influence of UV-VIS radiation but still characterized by high refractive index and high optical nonlinearities. The most exciting applications of these photoinduced effects in chalcogenide glass thin films include IR photonics (all-optical switching), micro(nano)-lithography, and phase-change memory devices.

As an outcome of the scientific part of the project, 15 peer-reviewed papers were published (11 in co-authorship with undergraduate students, 3 of them with undergraduate as a first author) and 37 presentations were made at international, national and regional conferences (30 of them in co-authorship with undergraduate students, 20 were personally presented by the undergraduate students). The most important scientific outcome of the Project is the quantification of photodarkening (photobleaching) and post-exposure relaxation kinetic curves, using stretch exponential Kohlrausch-type functions, including the analysis of the behavior of the exponential parameter β and the effective time relaxation constant τ in both As-S(Se) (pyramidal) and Ge-S(Se) (tetrahedral) binary chalcogenide glass thin films.  The dependence on energy, intensity and coherency of the light as well as film temperature, thickness and pre-treatment conditions were explored. The behavior of β and τ was related to the mechanisms of photostructural transformations.It allowed to propose atomistic picture of structural response to photoexposure including the dependence on photon energy and fluence for pyramidal and tetrahedral chalcogenide glass thin films produced from both technological methods.

This RUI project was excellent opportunity for the 14 undergraduate students from Austin Peay State University who participated to start their scientific career and improve their chances to be accepted to high profile graduate school. Most of the participating students were first generation college students and students from military families.  Four students were female.  Students who have graduated to date were admitted to graduate programs in such schools as Vanderbilt (Joshua Allen, Materials Science and Engineering), UCLA (Jonathan Bunton, Electrical and Computer Engineering), University of Tennessee Knoxville (Maria White, Theoretical Chemistry and Leo Saturday, Materials Science and Engineering), Case Western (Jeremy Trimble, Physics) and University of Central Florida (Justin Cook, Optics).

Project activity resulted in the development of several very productive international cooperative programs between APSU and known glass science institutions in Europe. Memoranda of Understanding were signed with University of Pardubice (Czech Republic), University of Rennes I (France), Rouen University (France) and University of Rzeszow (Poland). Thanks to the NSF funding, 3 undergraduate students from APSU (Jeremy Trimble, Justin Cook and Joshua Allen) spent 1 month each doing research and getting training at the University of Pardubice; 3 other students (Travis Hodge, Cord Beck and Austin Harnage) completed similar programs at the University of Rennes I. Both of these universities are known to be world leaders in glass science.   

Participation of undergraduate students in international, national and regional conferences was important part of the project's activity. We are very proud that Maria White (Latino female student) was awarded the 1st prize in the student poster contest at 2017 Annual GOMD Meeting in conjunction with PACRIM12 in Hawaii (it was joint competition for undergraduate and graduate students).

Successful scientific activity of undergraduate students participating in the Project helped them to be accepted into very prestigious and competitive summer programs at locacations such Princeton University (Joshua Allen, 2017 - Photonics REU), Tesla Inc. (Jonathan Bunton, 2017 - Internship), Oak Ridge National Laboratory (Laura Judy, 2016 - Computer Modeling REU), and the University of Michigan (Justin Cook, 2015 - Physics REU)

The most notable outreach activities within the Project were annual Materials Days, sugar glass demonstrations for elementary and high school students, glass demonstrations for high school students participating in annual Governor's School on Computational Physics, funding trip of non-science majors to Advanced Science Center in Nashville, TN.
